message: You have just missed your period, and you're already 5 weeks pregnant. Plan to go to the antenatal clinic soon
Share the secret of your pregnancy with your partner and your doctor. Your doctor will give you iron and folic acid tablets to help your baby grow well
Are you feeling sick? Most women do in early pregnancy. Try having some ginger or mint, and rest if you can
Your baby is the size of an orange seed. He already has tiny hands and feet and his heart is beating
Regular clinic visits in pregnancy help detect problems before they happen. Find out where your nearest clinic is for a healthy pregnancy
Spotting or light bleeding is worrying but very common in pregnancy. If you have bleeding with pain, contact the clinic immediately
Your baby's heart and brain are forming. Take iron and folic acid tablets daily to help her stay safe. You can get them free at the clinic
Eat well, so your baby will grow well. Try to eat some meat, eggs or beans every day with some green vegetables and milk, yoghurt or soya
Herbal concoctions are prohibited during pregnancy. They can harm your baby. Do not take any, no matter who they are from!
Your baby's bones are developing. You may feel sick or vomit. Eat when you can and drink plenty of clean water
Some medicines can harm your baby. If your friends and family suggest a medicine, always check with your doctor first before taking it
Have you been tested for HIV? Don?t be scared; get tested with your partner. If you have HIV, you can take steps to protect your baby
You are 2 months pregnant. Even though the baby inside you is tiny and you may be very tired. That's normal. Growing a baby is hard work!
Protect yourself from infections. Wash your hands with soap before you prepare meals, after using the toilet and after handling animals
Tetanus Toxoid vaccination is important in protecting you & your baby from infections during labour. Please visit your clinic to get the necessary vaccine
Your baby is now the size of a small cherry. Arrange to go to the clinic for a check-up and for your iron and folic acid tablets. Take these each day
It is important that you attend your antenatal clinic and see your doctor every FOUR weeks from now till you are 28 weeks pregnant!
Iodine helps your baby's brain develop. Salt often has iodine added to it. Ask at the clinic where you can buy iodised salt
Your baby is now the size of your thumb and is protected by the water he floats in, inside your womb
At the clinic you'll need a tetanus injection and a blood test to check your iron levels. Tests for STIs like syphilis and HIV can also be done
It is important to do an ultra sound scan very early in pregnancy. It helps your doctor accurately date the pregnancy and predict your due date
Drinking alcohol is bad for you and your baby. It could make your baby weak and ill. Never drink alcohol in pregnancy
If you have a fever, or start shaking and feeling sick, go to the clinic. A fever can affect your baby as well as you, and needs treating
Never take any drugs not prescribed by a doctor now that you?re pregnant!
Your baby is as big as half a banana! She is growing sucking muscles in her mouth. She will be ready to breastfeed as soon as she is born
Help your baby today with daily intake of folic acid and iron. Don?t postpone, start now!
Smoking harms you and your baby. If you smoke, your baby could be born weak and catch infections easily. Stop smoking and avoid smoky places
Congratulations!!! You made it through first trimester. Your risk of losing the baby is lower now. Nausea and tiredness will get better
Your baby is growing hair, and he can also grasp, frown and even suck his thumb! Try to eat an extra mouthful of food at each meal and extra snacks
You should begin to feel less sick now and get hungry instead. Eat fruit, vegetables, and meat or peas, and beans
Inside you, your baby will just fit in the palm of your hand. He even has tiny fingernails and eye lashes
Drinking alcohol can harm your baby. It can affect her growth. It's best not to have any alcohol. Drink plenty of clean water
Giving birth puts you and your baby at risk of tetanus. The Tetanus vaccine can protect you both. Ask your doctor about it
Your baby is now the size of a pear. He may have found his first toy - the umbilical cord! After the birth, keep the cord stump clean
Mosquitoes can cause illnesses like malaria. Always sleep under an insecticide-treated net to prevent mosquitoes from biting you
You will begin to feel your baby move/kick about around this time. This is a very special moment for mother and baby
Your baby is now the size of a small mango. If you are constipated, drink plenty of clean water and eat fruit and vegetables
Keeping clean helps protect you and your baby from infections. Wash your hands with soap after the toilet and before meals
You may need extra money during pregnancy, for travel to the clinic and for when your baby arrives. Start saving a little bit every day
Your baby is twice the size he was last week. He's moving more and you will feel him soon. He can hear your heartbeat now
Tired with headaches and dizziness? You may need iron. Remember to take your daily iron and folic acid pills. Get more from the clinic
Prevent malaria in pregnancy by taking the 1st dose of the preventive therapy. Talk to your doctor about it in your next clinic visit
Your baby has all her major organs now - the heart, liver and kidneys. She's even started developing taste buds on her tongue!
Ask about your blood group at the clinic. Check if relatives have the same blood group. Ask them if they will donate blood if you need it
It is important to do an ultra sound now. It helps to detect any abnormalities in the pregnancy early on
You're halfway through pregnancy! Your baby floats in fluid. This protects him from bumps, keeps him warm and lets him move around
The external sex organs of your baby are now clearly visible. You can now do an ultrasound scan to find out your baby?s sex
Feeling out of breath when you walk? Your womb is squashing your lungs now. Go to the clinic if you find you are breathless all the time
Your baby can hear your heartbeat and other noises from inside your body. He can hear your voice as well, so talk and sing to him
Go to the clinic if you have a fever, bleeding or pain when you pass urine. Make sure your family know these signs, too
You should be feeling your baby move/kick about by now. If not, talk to your doctor about it today
Your baby can turn over as well as kick. This is a good sign. Tell your doctor if you notice your baby moving much less than usual
As your baby grows inside you, he will need more food. Slowly increase the amount of food you eat as your stomach grows
Make water your friend. Drinking a glass of water between meals serves as nourishing fluid during pregnancy to increase blood volume needed for you and baby
Your baby now has definite times of sleeping and waking. He may wake you with his kicks. Go to the clinic if the kicks slow down or stop
If a family member has TB, they need treatment at the clinic. It will help protect you against TB too. You need to be healthy for your baby
The area around your nipples may become darker and your breasts may feel heavier now. Your body is preparing to breastfeed your baby
Remember NEVER to hide details of previous pregnancies, abortions or miscarriages from your doctor. ALL information is needed to make your pregnancy better
Your baby's sense of taste is developing, ready to enjoy your milk! Your breast milk will make your baby grow strong. It's the perfect food
In your next clinic visit, make sure you get more iron and folic acid tablets. If the clinic is out of stock, ask where else you can get them
Please visit the hospital IMMEDIATELY if you get severe or long-lasting headaches, feel dizzy or have blurred vision
Your baby is gaining fat. This fat will help keep him warm when he is born. You can help him by eating a few extra mouthfuls at each meal
Except your doctor advices against it, sex during pregnancy is perfectly okay during pregnancy. It helps you and your partner grow as a couple
Make a plan with your family to put your new baby to the breast in the first hour. Your creamy first milk will protect him from illness
Your baby is about the size of a pineapple. He is practising moving the muscles in his chest, so he will be ready to breathe at birth
Complications sometimes occur when giving birth. It's best to try and have your baby at a hospital; that way there'll be help at hand
Please visit the hospital IMMEDIATELY if you feel discomfort, pain or cramping in the lower abdomen or feel discomfort, pain, or burning when urinating
Babies dream at this stage in pregnancy. Perhaps he's dreaming about being born! If he's not as active as usual, tell your doctor
Calcium helps your baby's bones and teeth grow strong. Drink milk and eat beans or vegetables to get plenty of calcium
Slightly swollen hands and feet are common in pregnancy. But if you have sudden swelling and headaches, go to the clinic
Your baby responds to change - she may move when you undress! Feel thirsty and need to urinate a lot? Tell your doctor, it may be diabetes
It is important that you attend your antenatal clinic and see your doctor every TWO weeks from now till you are 36 weeks!
Drink plenty of water and eat fruit to keep your stools soft. If you have itching around the anus, wash the area after you open your bowels
Eat two extra mouthfuls of food at each meal and a healthy snack between meals. Eat something extra before you go to bed, too
If you need a blood transfusion, your friends and family can donate. Ask them to find out if their blood group matches yours
Are you having difficulty taking your pregnancy tablets like iron & folic acid? Try taking it along with foods like Eba, Amala, or Starch. It makes it easier to swallow
Your baby can open and close his eyes. Inside your womb, he can tell day from night by the way the light changes
Don?t ever feel sad about the sex of your baby. Be happy to carry that precious gift, no matter the sex
30 minutes of walking each day has loads of benefits for pregnant mums, and it doesn?t even have to be in one go!
It's best to give birth at the hospital. Find out the fastest way to get there. Get taxi numbers and enough phone balance for emergencies
The recommended weight gain during pregnancy is between 11kg to 16kg. Ensure healthy weight gain and if there are disturbing changes, see a doctor
Have you felt your belly tighten suddenly, then relax? This was a practice contraction. Your body is getting ready for labour
Your baby is getting plump! This body fat will keep him warm when he is born. Have 2 cloths ready. One to dry him and one to wrap him in
Have a hat or small cloth ready to cover your new baby's head. Babies lose lots of heat from their heads. Hold him close to keep him warm
The hospital is the safest place to deliver especially when in labour becomes complicated. Ensure to get registered in a hospital
Your baby may settle head down now, the best position to be born! You may find it harder to walk. It's time to slow down
ALWAYS wear a seatbelt whenever in cars, vans or trucks. Remember you have another life to also protect now
If your water breaks, go to the hospital. Your baby is at risk of infection. It may be a trickle or a gush
Your baby will drop lower now ready to be born. You will breathe more easily, but may also have to urinate more frequently
If you have previous history of difficulties in pregnancy or child birth, you may need to see your doctor even more often than usual
Sudden swelling of hands, face and feet is a sign of a problem. Tell your family, and ask them to take you to the clinic if they see this
Your body is designed to give birth. It will stretch and open with each contraction in labour, making space for your baby to be born
Breastfeeding is the best way. It is safe, prevents illness, and helps your baby grow strong. Let your baby suckle whenever he wants
Sometimes an operation is the safest way to have your baby. Choose a hospital where you trust the staff just in case you need an operation
The very 1st milk from your breast is called colostrum and it is very important your baby takes that milk. Don?t discard it!
It is important that you attend your antenatal clinic & see your doctor EVERY WEEK from now on till you deliver your baby!
You may need to continue taking iron pills for 3 months after your baby's birth. Go to the clinic for a final check-up and your iron pills
A cord infection can make your baby very ill. Sponge the cord with clean water and leave it uncovered to dry. Don't put anything else on it
Contrary to the movies, labour is not a 10 minute event; it lasts much longer than that. Be prepared for labour; talk to your doctor about what to expect
Don't bathe your baby for the first 6 hours of her life. Keep her well wrapped up and her head covered. The cord will drop off after a week
Your baby is curled up inside you all ready to be born. Talk to your doctor about the vaccinations your baby needs when she is born
A jelly-like substance on your underwear is a sign that labour will start soon. If you have bleeding like a period, go to the clinic
Low back pain is a sign that the baby is low down, ready to get born. Make sure you can get to the hospital in time
As you near due date, expect the process of labour to begin soon. Get excited as the final countdown will begin soon!
Your baby needs nothing else apart from breast milk for the first 6 months. Your milk will contain all the water and goodness he needs
Your baby will need the first dose of vaccines against polio and TB at birth. Make sure you baby gets them as soon as he is born
Your new baby needs your care. If she's having trouble breathing or feeding, is too hot or too cold, or doesn't respond, go to the clinic
Your newborn needs warmth. Nurse him on your bare chest under a blanket. Go to the hospital, if his eyes, palms and feet turn yellow
Do you know that contractions don?t stop after delivery? Never panic as your womb is contracting to prevent excess loss of blood
Like you, your baby is waiting for labour. You do this together! Make sure you have everything ready for labour
After birth you will bleed like a heavy period. So be prepared to change pads every 4-6 hours. Don't insert anything into your vagina
If your baby is still not here by now, let your doctor know. Make sure you can get to the clinic when labour does start
If by now your baby is still not here, visit the hospital immediately!
Regular, strong contractions are a sign of labour. If you feel them, go to the clinic immediately. Don't wait!
When your baby is here, talk to your doctor about anything. He is your friend
